items.title: RIS, Active RIS or RDARS: A Comparative Insight Through the Lens of Energy Efficiency
items.authors: Aparna V C, Shashank Shekhar, Sheetal Kalyani
items.institution: Indian Institute of Technology, Madras; PSG iTech
items.contributions: 1. Provides a unified comparative analysis of passive RIS, active RIS, and RDARS architectures in terms of coverage and energy efficiency. 2. Investigates the performance of these architectures in both sub-6GHz and mmWave frequency bands. 3. Analyzes the impact of reconfigurable surface placement and the number of elements on system performance.
items.summary: This paper compares three reconfigurable surface architectures—passive RIS, active RIS, and RDARS—to address the problem of multiplicative fading in wireless networks. The analysis evaluates their coverage and energy efficiency across sub-6GHz and mmWave bands, considering placement and element count. The main conclusion is that RDARS is highly energy-efficient for sub-6GHz systems, active RIS excels in mmWave systems, and traditional RIS remains more efficient for scenarios with fewer elements or near users.

items.title: Optimal Beamforming Design for Multi-user MIMO Near-Field ISAC Systems with Movable Antennas
items.authors: Nemanja Stefan Perović, Keshav Singh, Chih-Peng Li, Octavia A. Dobre, Mark F. Flanagan
items.institution: National Sun Yat-sen University, Memorial University of Newfoundland, University College Dublin
items.contributions: 1. Proposes an optimization framework for MA-enabled near-field ISAC systems to maximize communication WSR under a sensing constraint. 2. Develops alternating optimization algorithms for beamforming and antenna positioning for both linear and ZF precoding schemes. 3. Demonstrates the substantial performance advantage of using MAs over fixed antennas in near-field ISAC and analyzes the impact of interference and sensing thresholds.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of optimizing beamforming and antenna positioning for multi-user MIMO near-field ISAC systems with movable antennas. The authors propose alternating optimization algorithms for linear and ZF precoding to maximize the weighted sum rate for communication while meeting a sensing requirement. Simulation results show that using movable antennas provides significant performance gains over fixed antennas in near-field scenarios.

items.title: An Improved Lower Bound on Cardinality of Support of the Amplitude-Constrained AWGN Channel
items.authors: Haiyang Wang, Luca Barletta, Alex Dytso
items.institution: Yale University, Politecnico di Milano, Qualcomm Flarion Technology, Inc.
items.contributions: 1. Quantified the closeness of the capacity-achieving output distribution to the uniform distribution within the amplitude constraint. 2. Introduced a novel wrapping operation to map the problem to a compact domain and developed a theory for best approximation of the uniform distribution by finite Gaussian mixtures. 3. Combined these new approximation bounds with stability properties of optimal distributions to establish an improved lower bound on the support size, disproving a previous conjecture of linear scaling.
items.summary: This paper studies the amplitude-constrained additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel. The authors develop a new method involving a wrapping operation and approximation theory for Gaussian mixtures to prove that the number of points in the capacity-achieving input distribution scales at least as fast as A√log A, improving the previous lower bound and disproving the conjecture of linear scaling.

items.title: Iterative Channel Estimation, Detection and Decoding for Multi-Antenna Systems with RIS
items.authors: Roberto C. G. Porto, Rodrigo C. de Lamare
items.institution: Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel iterative code-aided channel estimation (ICCE) technique using LDPC codes and encoded pilots to improve accuracy and reduce pilot overhead. 2. Introduces an iterative channel tracking (ICT) method to leverage temporal channel correlation for further performance enhancement. 3. Provides an analytical evaluation of the proposed estimator in terms of normalized mean-squared error (NMSE), computational complexity, and code rate impact, validated in multi-RIS scenarios.
items.summary: This paper addresses the high pilot overhead and estimation difficulty in multi-user, multi-antenna systems assisted by multiple Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS). It proposes an iterative channel estimation, detection, and decoding (ICEDD) scheme that uses encoded pilots and LDPC codes to refine channel estimates iteratively, combined with a channel tracking method. The approach is analytically evaluated and shown to perform well in sub-6 GHz multi-RIS scenarios under various conditions.

items.title: Beyond Beam Sweeping: One-Shot Satellite Acquisition with Doppler-Aware Rainbow Beamforming
items.authors: Juha Park, Ian P. Roberts, Wonjae Shin
items.institution: Korea University, University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a one-shot satellite acquisition framework that leverages Doppler and beam-squint effects, traditionally seen as impairments, to avoid time-domain beam sweeping. 2. Derives a closed-form "rainbow beamformer" that aligns frequency-dependent beam directions with satellite positions inferred from Doppler shifts, enabling simultaneous multi-satellite reception. 3. Develops three Doppler-aware angle estimation algorithms to extract satellite position information from received signals.
items.summary: The paper addresses the high overhead and latency of conventional beam sweeping for LEO satellite acquisition. It proposes a one-shot acquisition method using a novel "rainbow beamformer" that exploits Doppler and beam-squint effects to map frequency to beam direction, allowing full angular coverage with a single transmission. Simulation results show the method significantly outperforms conventional approaches in accuracy and speed.

items.title: Covering in Hamming and Grassmann Spaces: New Bounds and Reed--Solomon-Based Constructions
items.authors: Samin Riasat, Hessam Mahdavifar
items.contributions: 1. Introduced the average covering radius as a new performance metric and derived non-asymptotic random-coding bounds for it in Hamming and Grassmann spaces. 2. Developed efficient puncturing-based covering algorithms for Generalized Reed-Solomon (GRS) codes in Hamming space. 3. Proposed a new family of subspace codes called Character-Reed-Solomon (CRS) codes for Grassmann space and showed their strong average covering performance.
items.summary: This paper studies covering problems in Hamming and Grassmann spaces by introducing the average covering radius as a measure of distortion. It proposes new constructions using Reed-Solomon codes and their subspace variants, showing that these structured codes achieve strong average performance, often outperforming random codes, despite poor worst-case guarantees.

items.title: Generalized Hyperderivative Reed-Solomon Codes
items.authors: Mahir Bilen Can, Benjamin Horowitz
items.contributions: 1) Proposes Generalized Hyperderivative Reed-Solomon (GHRS) codes, a novel family that generalizes NRT Reed-Solomon codes. 2) Proves that every GHRS code is MDS and that the dual of a GHRS code is also a GHRS code. 3) Identifies subfamilies of GHRS codes that are low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes and quasi-cyclic codes, with some codes possessing all these properties simultaneously.
items.summary: This paper introduces Generalized Hyperderivative Reed-Solomon (GHRS) codes, a new family that generalizes NRT Reed-Solomon codes. The main results prove that GHRS codes are MDS, closed under duality, and include subfamilies that are both LDPC and quasi-cyclic, offering a unique combination of optimal error correction and practical sparse structure.

items.title: Trust Region Masking for Long-Horizon LLM Reinforcement Learning
items.authors: Yingru Li, Jiacai Liu, Jiawei Xu, Yuxuan Tong, Ziniu Li, Baoxiang Wang
items.institution: (Institutions not explicitly listed in provided content; inferred from author names and common affiliations in the field, but not specified. Therefore, output is left blank.)
items.contributions: 1. Deriving two novel, tighter theoretical bounds (Pinsker-Marginal and Mixed) on the approximation error in off-policy LLM-RL, scaling better with sequence length than classical O(T^2) bounds. 2. Identifying that these bounds depend on a sequence-level quantity (maximum token-level KL divergence) that cannot be controlled by token-independent methods like PPO clipping. 3. Proposing the Trust Region Masking (TRM) algorithm, which masks entire sequences from gradient updates to enforce the trust region, providing non-vacuous monotonic improvement guarantees for long-horizon tasks.
items.summary: The paper addresses the problem that classical trust region bounds become vacuous for long-horizon LLM reinforcement learning due to unavoidable off-policy mismatch. It proposes Trust Region Masking (TRM), a method that excludes entire sequences from gradient computation if any token violates a trust region constraint. This approach, supported by new tighter theoretical bounds, provides the first non-vacuous monotonic improvement guarantees for long-horizon LLM-RL.

items.title: A New Family of Binary Sequences via Elliptic Function Fields over Finite Fields of Odd Characteristics
items.authors: Xiaofeng Liu, Jun Zhang, Fang-Wei Fu
items.contributions: 1. Extends the construction of binary sequences from cyclic elliptic function fields over fields of characteristic 2 to those of odd characteristic. 2. Introduces the use of the quadratic residue map (η) instead of the trace map for sequence generation. 3. Provides theoretical bounds for the key properties (balance, correlation, linear complexity) of the new family of sequences.
items.summary: This paper constructs a new family of binary sequences using cyclic elliptic function fields over finite fields of odd characteristic, employing a quadratic residue map. It derives theoretical upper bounds for the sequences' balance and correlation, and a lower bound for their linear complexity, thus extending prior work from characteristic 2.

items.title: Sum Rate optimization for RIS-Aided RSMA system with Movable Antenna
items.authors: Mingyu Hu, Nan Liu, Wei Kang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel movable-antenna (MA) assisted RSMA-RIS framework to enhance spatial degrees of freedom and system performance. 2. Formulates and solves a joint optimization problem for beamforming, RIS reflection, rate splitting, and MA positions using FP and KKT conditions. 3. Demonstrates through numerical results that MA provides additional performance gains for RSMA, even with RIS assistance, and yields greater gains for RSMA compared to SDMA.
items.summary: This paper proposes a novel wireless communication system that integrates movable antennas (MAs) with a Rate-Splitting Multiple Access (RSMA) framework aided by a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS). To maximize the sum rate, the authors formulate a joint optimization problem and solve it using fractional programming and KKT conditions to derive updates for beamforming, RIS reflection, and MA positions. The results show that incorporating MAs provides significant additional performance improvements for RSMA systems compared to traditional fixed-antenna setups.

items.title: Information Inequalities for Five Random Variables
items.authors: E.P. Csirmaz, L. Csirmaz
items.contributions: 1. Applied a variant of the Maximum Entropy Method with computational optimizations to calculate all five-variable non-Shannon inequalities from the first nine generations. 2. Defined and proved two infinite collections of five-variable non-Shannon entropy inequalities. 3. Developed an algorithm to enumerate all extremal inequalities based on parameterizing downward closed subsets of lattice points.
items.summary: This paper investigates the structure of the entropy region for five discrete random variables, a largely unknown area. The authors employ a computationally optimized variant of the Maximum Entropy Method to generate and analyze non-Shannon inequalities. They successfully define infinite families of such inequalities and propose an algorithm for enumerating extremal ones, conjecturing these results fully characterize their method's output.

items.title: Faster-than-Nyquist Signaling for Next-Generation Wireless: Principles, Applications, and Challenges
items.authors: Shuangyang Li, Melda Yuksel, Tongyang Xu, Shinya Sugiura, Jinhong Yuan, Giuseppe Caire, Lajos Hanzo
items.institution: Technical University of Berlin, Middle East Technical University, University College London, The University of Tokyo, University of New South Wales, University of Southampton
items.contributions: 1. Provides a structured introduction to FTN signaling, covering its principles, theoretical foundations, and unique advantages. 2. Presents promising results for coded FTN systems, demonstrating their potential for high spectral efficiency. 3. Highlights the compelling advantages of FTN signaling for integrated sensing and communications (ISAC), a key function for future networks.
items.summary: This paper introduces Faster-than-Nyquist (FTN) signaling as a solution to increase spectral efficiency in next-generation wireless networks without using more bandwidth. It explains the core principles of FTN, presents results for coded FTN systems, and discusses its application in integrated sensing and communications. The paper concludes by outlining open research challenges and future directions for FTN technology.

items.title: Dynamic Channel Knowledge Map Construction in MIMO-OFDM Systems
items.authors: Wenjun Jiang, Xiaojun Yuan, Chenchen Liu, Boyu Teng
items.institution: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC)
items.contributions: 1. Proposed a dynamic channel model for MIMO-OFDM systems that accounts for quasi-static and dynamic scatterers, antenna rotation, and synchronization errors. 2. Formulated the dynamic CKM construction problem within a Bayesian inference framework and designed a novel two-stage approximate Bayesian inference algorithm. 3. Developed a high-performance algorithm for quasi-static parameter inference and a low-complexity algorithm for dynamic parameter estimation, enabling efficient and accurate channel estimation in dynamic environments.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of constructing Channel Knowledge Maps (CKM) in dynamic environments for MIMO-OFDM systems. It proposes a two-stage Bayesian inference method that first estimates quasi-static parameters and then uses them as priors to efficiently estimate dynamic parameters from limited real-time data. The method is shown to enable low-overhead, high-performance channel estimation in dynamic settings.

items.title: Affine-Projection Recovery of Continuous Angular Power Spectrum: Geometry and Resolution
items.authors: Shengsong Luo, Ruilin Wu, Chongbin Xu, Junjie Ma, Xiaojun Yuan, Xin Wang
items.institution: Fudan University, Peking University, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
items.contributions: 1. Provides a geometric interpretation of the PLV algorithm by analyzing it in a weighted Fourier-domain, leading to an explicit trigonometric-polynomial representation. 2. Derives a closed-form solution via a positive-definite matrix, which guarantees uniqueness of the recovered APS. 3. Establishes an exact energy identity that characterizes the reconstruction error and provides a sharp identifiability condition: perfect recovery occurs if and only if the true APS lies within the identified subspace; otherwise, PLV returns the minimum-energy consistent spectrum.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of recovering a continuous angular power spectrum (APS) from a spatial channel covariance matrix. It builds upon the Projection onto Linear Variety (PLV) algorithm, analyzing it in a weighted Fourier-domain to enhance geometric interpretability, which yields a closed-form solution and a sharp characterization of identifiability and resolution. The main conclusion is that PLV achieves perfect recovery only when the true APS lies in a specific trigonometric-polynomial subspace; otherwise, it returns the minimum-energy spectrum consistent with the covariance.

items.title: Active Nonparametric Two-Sample Testing by Betting on Heterogeneous Data Sources
items.authors: Chia-Yu Hsu, Shubhanshu Shekhar
items.contributions: 1. Proposes an active, nonparametric sequential two-sample testing procedure for multiple heterogeneous data sources, which works under minimal distributional assumptions., 2. Introduces an adaptive source-selection strategy that mixes exploitation (based on empirical distinguishability) and exploration (via a vanishing greedy strategy) within the testing-by-betting framework., 3. Theoretically establishes that the test controls type-I error, has power-one under the alternative, and provides a bound on expected sample size, characterizing the improvement over passive sampling.
items.summary: The paper addresses the problem of active, sequential two-sample testing across multiple heterogeneous data sources where distributions are nonparametric. It proposes a method that adaptively selects data sources using an explore-exploit strategy and updates a betting wealth martingale to make decisions. The main conclusion is that this approach controls type-I error, ensures power-one detection, and achieves faster decisions compared to passive testing, quantifying the gains of adaptive sampling.

items.title: Flexible Intelligent Metasurface for Downlink Communications under Statistical CSI
items.authors: Vaibhav Kumar, Anastasios Papazafeiropoulos, Pandelis Kourtessis, John Senior, Marwa Chafii, Dimitra I. Kaklamani, Iakovos S. Venieris
items.institution: New York University Abu Dhabi, University of Hertfordshire, National Technical University of Athens
items.contributions: 1. Departing from prior works that rely on instantaneous CSI, this paper addresses the problem of average sum spectral efficiency maximization under statistical CSI for a FIM-assisted downlink system. 2. Derives the spatial correlation matrix for the FIM-aided transmitter, a key modeling contribution. 3. Proposes an iterative FIM optimization algorithm based on the gradient projection method to solve the non-convex optimization problem.
items.summary: This paper proposes a method to optimize a Flexible Intelligent Metasurface (FIM) for downlink communications using only statistical Channel State Information (CSI), rather than instantaneous CSI. The method involves deriving the FIM's spatial correlation matrix and applying a gradient projection-based algorithm to maximize the average sum spectral efficiency. Simulation results show the FIM-aided system provides significant performance gains over rigid antenna arrays in scenarios with strong spatial channel correlation.

items.title: Identifying faulty edges in resistive electrical networks
items.authors: Barbara Fiedorowicz, Amitabh Basu

Proves rigorous upper and lower bounds on the optimal number of measurements for various graph classes. 3. Demonstrates that the proposed measurement strategies are optimal for several graph classes, as the bounds are tight.
items.summary: The paper studies the problem of identifying faulty resistors in an electrical network by measuring effective resistances between node pairs. The authors propose strategies to minimize the number of such measurements needed for diagnosis. They prove tight upper and lower bounds on this number for different graph classes, establishing the optimality of their approach.

items.authors: Natasha Fernandes, Annabelle McIver, Parastoo Sadeghi

Derives novel general composition theorems for f-DP enabled by this equivalence. 3. Applies the new composition theorems to analyze privacy amplification mechanisms like sub-sampling and purification, producing new f-DP profiles for these algorithms.

This foundational link enables the derivation of new, general composition theorems for f-DP. The authors apply these theorems to analyze complex privacy-enhancing algorithms, such as sub-sampling, yielding improved privacy profiles.

items.title: Learning to Reconfigure: Using Device Status to Select the Right Constrained Coding Scheme
items.authors: Doğukan Özbayrak, Ahmed Hareedy
items.contributions: 1. Proposes offline and online learning methods to reconfigure constrained coding schemes based on actual device status, moving beyond predetermined time stamps. 2. Models the reconfiguration problem as a linear programming optimization to maximize storage capacity and/or minimize decoding complexity, proving global optimality. 3. Demonstrates the effectiveness of the approach through experimental results in Two-Dimensional Magnetic Recording (TDMR) systems.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of optimally reconfiguring constrained coding schemes in storage devices as they age. The authors propose offline and online learning methods that fit device status data to polynomial models and formulate the reconfiguration decision as a linear programming problem to maximize capacity or minimize complexity. Experimental results show the proposed method is effective for TDMR systems and can be extended to other storage or transmission systems.

It formulates the problem as an electrostatic equilibrium and solves it efficiently using an ODE-based framework and eigenvalue decomposition. The method shows significant gains in spectral efficiency and robustness, with an asymptotic closed-form solution closely approaching the optimum.

items.authors: Shizhe He, Avanika Narayan, Ishan S. Khare, Scott W. Linderman, Christopher Ré, Dan Biderman

Introduces a task-independent estimator of mutual information between context and compression to quantify compression quality. 3. Empirically demonstrates that scaling compressor models is more effective than scaling predictors for performance and cost, enabling efficient on-device compression.

It proposes an information-theoretic framework using mutual information to evaluate compressors, finding that larger compressors are more accurate, concise, and information-dense, making scaling compressors more effective than scaling predictors for cost-efficient performance.

items.title: Conserved active information
items.authors: Yanchen Chen, Daniel Andrés Díaz-Pachón
items.contributions: 1. Introduces conserved active information (I⊕), a symmetric measure of net information gain/loss across a search space that respects No-Free-Lunch conservation. 2. Demonstrates that I⊕ can reveal regimes (e.g., strong knowledge reducing global disorder) that are hidden from traditional measures like KL divergence. 3. Applies the framework to resolve a longstanding critique of active information and illustrates its utility in domains like Markov chains and cosmological fine-tuning.
items.summary: This paper proposes a new information-theoretic measure called conserved active information (I⊕) to quantify net information change in search problems while respecting conservation laws. It shows that I⊕ uncovers scenarios, such as strong knowledge imposing order, which are missed by standard divergence measures. The work resolves a key critique of active information and enables applications in search and optimization.

items.authors: Mohsen Amidzadeh

Introduces a novel forward-backward Markov decision process (FB-MDP) model that captures both the forward dynamics of user preferences and the backward dynamics of latency in a cache-aided multicast network. 2. Proposes a forward-backward multi-objective reinforcement learning (FB-MORL) algorithm to optimize for expected latency, outage probability, and resource consumption simultaneously. 3. Demonstrates through simulation that the proposed FB-MORL algorithm can find a promising dynamic cache policy for latency-optimal streaming.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of optimizing streaming latency in a cellular network with cache-enabled base stations using multicast. The authors propose a novel forward-backward reinforcement learning framework that models the network's temporal dynamics as a multi-objective Markov decision process. Simulation results show their method is effective in finding a dynamic cache policy that reduces latency.

It proposes a novel closed-form lower bound for the capacity under Rayleigh fading, which is tight for all SNR values and valid for finite system sizes. The work also includes a detailed low-SNR analysis to understand the impact of system parameters on performance.

It proposes a three-phase method involving faulty antenna detection via compressed sensing, phase calibration, and efficient localization, which is shown to significantly reduce errors compared to benchmarks, especially for short ranges or high fault probabilities.

items.title: Rational Inattention: A Bayesian Predictive Approach
items.authors: Nicholas G. Polson, Daniel Zantedeschi
items.institution: University of Chicago, University of South Florida
items.contributions: 1. Recasts rational inattention as a Bayesian predictive decision problem, linking it to rate-distortion theory and showing Shannon entropy emerges endogenously as the honest local utility. 2. Establishes a supported complete-class result proving optimal policies are Gibbs-Boltzmann channels, recovering classical rational-inattention models as a special case. 3. Demonstrates that canonical models (multinomial logit, James-Stein shrinkage, LQG control) are geometric specializations of this unified framework, reframing bounded rationality as an optimal design principle.
items.summary: The paper recasts rational inattention as a Bayesian predictive decision problem where an agent reports a predictive distribution evaluated by a proper local scoring rule. This framework shows that information costs arise endogenously as expected predictive utility, leading to optimal Gibbs-Boltzmann channel policies. The main conclusion is that bounded rationality behaviors like soft choice and regularization emerge rationally from the geometry of predictive refinement, not from assumed cognitive frictions.

items.title: Poincaré Duality and Multiplicative Structures on Quantum Codes
items.authors: Yiming Li, Zimu Li, Zi-Wen Liu, Quynh T. Nguyen
items.contributions: 1. Generalizing Poincaré duality from manifolds to sheaf-based classical and quantum codes, establishing a rigorous duality relationship between chain and cochain complexes. 2. Constructing multiplicative structures (cup and cap products) on sheaved chain complexes, leading to an explicit isomorphism between (co)homology groups. 3. Applying the framework to obtain transversal logical gates (CZ, CCZ, higher-order controlled-Z) on families of good qLDPC and quantum locally testable codes, pointing towards fault-tolerant non-Clifford gates.
items.summary: This paper generalizes Poincaré duality and multiplicative structures from topology to sheaf-based quantum codes. The authors rigorously prove duality relationships and construct cup/cap products, leading to an isomorphism between homology groups. As an application, they demonstrate how to construct transversal logical non-Clifford gates on good quantum LDPC codes, advancing fault-tolerant quantum computing.

It proposes an information-theoretic model for QSS rate analysis, connects it to compound quantum channels, and provides a regularized capacity formula. items.authors: Xinyi Guo, Li You, Qiong Liu, Xiqi Gao, Xiang-Gen Xia
items.institution: Southeast University, Purple Mountain Laboratories, Sorbonne University, University of Delaware

Derived tractable analytical expressions for the conditional received rate, its spatial average, and higher-order statistics via the meta distribution. 3. Showed that the framework generalizes existing NOMA and OMA analyses and provides new insights into how discrete rate adaptation reshapes interference dynamics and fairness in dense networks.

The framework jointly captures spatial interference and discrete rate behavior, enabling the derivation of key performance metrics. The results show that the framework generalizes prior analyses and offers new insights into interference management and fairness in dense RSMA networks.

It proposes a knowledge-driven semantic communication framework where a UAV measures and transmits semantic features to a ground device, which then uses a novel KE-VQ-Transformer model to complete the map, incorporating physical signal propagation constraints. items.title: Coding-Logic Correspondence: Turning Information and Communication Networks into Logical Formulae via Hypergraph Heyting Algebra
items.authors: Cheuk Ting Li
items.institution: The Chinese University of Hong Kong
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a new model of information using confusion hypergraphs (hyperconfusions) instead of random variables. 2. Establishes that information modeled this way forms a Heyting algebra, enabling logical operations (conjunction, disjunction, implication). 3. Introduces a "coding-logic correspondence" that expresses communication network requirements as logical formulae, allowing direct computation of optimal coding schemes with cost given by hypergraph entropy.
items.summary: The paper proposes modeling information using confusion hypergraphs, which allows information to form a Heyting algebra and be manipulated with logical operations. This connection enables the requirements of communication networks (like network coding) to be expressed as logical formulae, from which optimal coding schemes can be directly computed, with the communication cost linked to hypergraph entropy. This establishes a novel correspondence between coding problems and logic, analogous to the Curry-Howard correspondence.

items.title: Learning-Enabled Elastic Network Topology for Distributed ISAC Service Provisioning
items.authors: Jie Chen, Xianbin Wang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes an elastic network topology (ENT) that dynamically aggregates localized cell-centric networks into federated cell-free networks to balance signaling overhead and resource utilization for distributed ISAC services. 2. Develops a two-phase operation protocol for autonomous service classification and resource partitioning, and a utility-to-signaling ratio (USR) metric to quantify the performance-overhead tradeoff. 3. Formulates a USR maximization problem and addresses it with a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) framework to handle the distributed optimization and incomplete channel state information.
items.summary: This paper proposes an elastic network topology to flexibly support distributed integrated sensing and communication services by dynamically aggregating cell-centric networks into cell-free federations. A two-phase protocol and a utility-to-signaling ratio metric are introduced, and the resulting optimization problem is solved using a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning approach. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed design and algorithm.

items.title: Leveraging Overfitting for Low-Complexity and Modality-Agnostic Joint Source-Channel Coding
items.authors: Haotian Wu, Gen Li, Pier Luigi Dragotti, Deniz Gündüz
items.contributions: 1. Introduces Implicit-JSCC, a novel overfitted JSCC paradigm that directly optimizes channel symbols and a lightweight decoder per source instance, eliminating the need for training datasets or pre-trained models., 2. Achieves a low-complexity solution with ~1000x lower decoding complexity than existing methods, using as few as 607 parameters and 641 multiplications per pixel., 3. Provides a storage-free, modality-agnostic design that inherently addresses source generalizability and achieves state-of-the-art performance in high SNR regimes, suitable for streaming scenarios.
items.summary: This paper proposes Implicit-JSCC, a novel joint source-channel coding method that leverages overfitting to create instance-specific, lightweight encoders and decoders for each data source. This approach eliminates the need for large models or training datasets, drastically reducing decoding complexity and storage overhead while being agnostic to data modality. The method achieves state-of-the-art performance at high signal-to-noise ratios, demonstrating its potential for efficient communication in edge and streaming systems.

items.title: Adjusted Kolmogorov Complexity of Binary Words with Empirical Entropy Normalization
items.authors: Brani Vidakovic
items.contributions: 1. Introduces a new entropy-normalized complexity measure for binary words, defined as the ratio of Kolmogorov complexity to empirical entropy, to separate intrinsic descriptive complexity from symbol imbalance. 2. Proves that for Martin-Löf random sequences under constructive exchangeable measures, the adjusted complexity grows linearly and converges to one. 3. Demonstrates through a pathological construction that the regularity of the underlying measure is essential for this convergence result.
items.summary: This paper introduces a new measure of complexity for binary words by normalizing Kolmogorov complexity with the word's empirical entropy, aiming to isolate intrinsic algorithmic structure from the combinatorial effect of imbalanced symbol frequencies. The authors prove that for random sequences under certain measures, this adjusted complexity converges to one, and show that the regularity of the measure is crucial. The framework connects Kolmogorov complexity, entropy, and randomness, with potential applications in randomness testing and structured data analysis.

items.title: Solomonoff-Inspired Hypothesis Ranking with LLMs for Prediction Under Uncertainty
items.authors: Josh Barber, Rourke Young, Cameron Coombe, Will Browne
items.summary: This paper proposes a method that uses a Solomonoff-inspired scoring to weight hypotheses generated by a Large Language Model based on their simplicity and predictive fit. The method, applied to Mini-ARC tasks, produces uncertainty-aware predictions by spreading probability across multiple hypotheses, contrasting with Bayesian Model Averaging which tends to concentrate weight on a single candidate. The results highlight the value of algorithmic information-theoretic priors for robust, interpretable reasoning under uncertainty.

items.title: Timely Information Updating for Mobile Devices Without and With ML Advice
items.authors: Yu-Pin Hsu, Yi-Hsuan Tseng
items.summary: This paper proposes an online algorithm for a mobile device to decide when to send status updates to an access point, balancing information timeliness and update cost. The algorithm achieves an optimal competitive ratio against adversarial uncertainties and, when augmented with machine learning advice, attains an optimal consistency-robustness trade-off. The main conclusion is that an optimal competitive algorithm exhibits a threshold-like response to ML advice, either fully trusting or completely ignoring it.

items.title: Time-Frequency Analysis for Neural Networks
items.authors: Ahmed Abdeljawad, Elena Cordero
items.institution: Johann Radon Institute of Computational and Applied Mathematics (RICAM), Austrian Academy of Sciences; Università degli Studi di Torino
items.summary: This paper develops a quantitative approximation theory for shallow neural networks using time-frequency analysis and weighted modulation spaces. It proves dimension-independent approximation rates in Sobolev norms for networks combining standard activations with localized time-frequency windows, achieving better performance than standard ReLU networks.

items.title: Information theory and discriminative sampling for model discovery
items.authors: Yuxuan Bao, J. Nathan Kutz
items.summary: This paper uses the Fisher Information Matrix within the SINDy framework to quantify the information content in different segments of dynamical system trajectories. It demonstrates that prioritizing more informative data through information-theoretic metrics improves sampling efficiency and model performance in data-driven model discovery.

items.title: Large Model Enabled Embodied Intelligence for 6G Integrated Perception, Communication, and Computation Network
items.authors: Zhuoran Li, Zhen Gao, Xinhua Liu, Zheng Wang, Xiaotian Zhou, Lei Liu, Yongpeng Wu, Wei Feng, Yongming Huang
items.summary: This paper proposes using Large AI Models (LAMs) to transform base stations into Intelligent Base Station Agents (IBSAs) for 6G networks, integrating perception, communication, and computation. The core method involves a perception-cognition-execution pipeline with cloud-edge-end collaboration and parameter-efficient adaptation. The main conclusion is that LAM-enabled IBSAs represent a practical path toward building native, safety-critical 6G systems.

items.title: Non-Linear Strong Data-Processing for Quantum Hockey-Stick Divergences
items.authors: Theshani Nuradha, Ian George, Christoph Hirche
items.institution: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, National University of Singapore, Leibniz Universität Hannover
items.summary: This paper establishes non-linear strong data-processing inequalities (SDPI) for quantum hockey-stick divergences, improving upon existing linear bounds. The method involves defining Fγ curves to characterize SDPI for sequential compositions of noisy quantum channels. The results enable tighter finite mixing time bounds and stronger privacy guarantees for sequential private quantum channels.

items.title: Multi-Modal Semantic Communication
items.authors: Matin Mortaheb, Erciyes Karakaya, Sennur Ulukus
items.summary: The paper proposes a multi-modal semantic communication framework that uses text-based user queries and a cross-modal attention mechanism to guide the extraction and adaptive-resolution transmission of task-relevant image patches. This approach overcomes limitations of self-attention-only methods in complex scenes and enables flexible, efficient communication under bandwidth constraints.
